answers.author: Tim Bonnemann
answers.text:
In 2009, we launched ParticipateDB ( http://participatedb.com ), a database that collects citizen engagement tools as well as project examples. For example: 
Facebook:  http://participatedb.com/tools/51 
Twitter:  http://participatedb.com/tools/35 
We don't try to rate each project's success, and some projects have certainly struggled. Nonetheless, you should be able to find some good or even inspiring examples. 
Let me know if you come across any other tools or projects, and we'll happily add them. Thanks!

answers.author: Maria Lasday
answers.text:
Bannockburn, IL sends out a citizen survey to the residents every year. In the survey, there is a section for comments. It helps to know how the Village is doing, what their concerns are, and their views on certain programs and policies. In addition, Bannockburn sends out a newsletter every two months and has a Community Day (gathering for all of the residents) every August.

Part of the technology that we will reach out to our citizens include Facebook, and croudsoucing UserVoice tools.  http://www.mesaaz.gov/imesa/

answers.author: Michael Huggins
answers.text:
I've worked with a group of community volunteers to launch an online community forum, hosted by E-Democracy.org. The forum opened early with about 150 registrants. Participants need to register, use their real names, be civil, and limit posts to two per day. The community group promoting the forum are describing it as an "online backyard fence" where residents can talk about local issues, concerns, promote community events, ask questions, and perhaps find lost pets. The City is looking at how to integrate future comprehensive planning face-to-face forums with the online conversations.
